objectives.description: Understand the fundamental difference between a job and a career, and why it matters for your future.
Identify your personal interests, skills, and values for informed career exploration.
Use career exploration resources like O*NET, BLS, and informational interviews effectively.
Develop SMART career goals and create a comprehensive career development plan.

terms.definition: A long-term professional journey encompassing multiple jobs, involving growth, development, and advancement over time.
terms.example: Starting as a staff accountant, then senior accountant, manager, and eventually CFO over 20 years

terms.definition: A specific position or role with defined responsibilities, typically performed in exchange for payment.
terms.example: Working as a cashier at a retail store or an administrative assistant at a company

terms.definition: The process of evaluating your own interests, skills, values, and personality traits to guide career decisions.
terms.example: Taking personality tests, listing skills, reflecting on what motivates you

terms.definition: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound objectives for effective planning.
terms.example: "Complete my CPA certification exam within 18 months of graduation"

leftPanel.title: Three Key Areas to Explore
paragraphs: 1. Interests: What subjects do you enjoy? What activities make time fly? What problems do you like solving?
2. Skills: What are you naturally good at? What have you learned through education or experience?
3. Values: What matters most to you in work? What kind of environment do you thrive in?

items: What do I lose track of time doing?

leftPanel.title: Online Research Tools
paragraphs: O*NET OnLine (onetonline.org): Comprehensive database with skills, education, salary, and outlook for hundreds of occupations.
Bureau of Labor Statistics: Occupational Outlook Handbook with detailed career information and employment projections.
CareerOneStop: Career assessments, training opportunities, and job search resources.
What exactly do you want to accomplish? Who is involved? Why is this important?
How will you track progress? What metrics will show you've achieved it?
Is this realistic given your resources, time, and current situation?
Does this align with your broader career aspirations and personal values?
What is your target date for completion? When will you reach milestones?

scenario.name: Sarah: From Job to Career in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Sarah started as a receptionist at a medical clinic right after high school‚Äîviewing it as just a job to pay bills.
After observing nurses and medical assistants, she became interested in healthcare as a career. She created a development plan with short, mid, and long-term goals.
Her transformation: complete nursing prerequisites, earn RN license, then specialize in pediatric oncology and eventually become a pediatric nurse practitioner.

scenario.name: Miguel: Career Exploration Process in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Miguel, a high school junior interested in technology, wasn't sure which specific career to pursue.
Self-assessment: Identified strengths in problem-solving, communication, and creativity; interests in coding, design, and helping others use technology.
Research: Used the Occupational Outlook Handbook to compare Software Developer, UX/UI Designer, IT Support Specialist, and Computer Science Teacher.
Informational Interviews: Conversations revealed that UX/UI design best combined his technical and creative interests.
